male name

back, particularly the part with the spinal column

bare slab of rock on a mountain top

poetry genre, aka “Grand Sekimbāt”; it contains 3 sekimbāt; a prologue (uššua “head”), the main body (tarti “body”), and an epilogue (eš “tail”). The middle sekimbāt, the tarti, deviates from typical sekimbāt in that an indefinite number of quatrains may
poetry genre, starting and ending with two-line stanzas, and the body containing quatrains. Also: “hipixna”

poetry genre; stanzas organized into six lines each (hence the term “silix-iskut”, lit “six-line”); as in the majority of Minhast poetry, is narrated in the first person. Unlike the sekimbāt, there is only one viewpoint presented. For an example, see “Ir
poison arrows filled with venom of the yakkūn plant

sand (blown or swirling from sea/ocean winds, or winds coming from the land toward the ocean, as opposed to sand blown in say, like desert or other landlocked winds)
sand (filled with small pebbles and bits of shell)
sand (like ittarsa, except it blows into your eyes)
sand (like ittarsa, except it stings exposed skin or flesh)

sand (the powdery type that forms sand dunes)

sand (with sea grasses or other plants sticking out of it)

sand that is cool for walking on
sand that is wet (wet in a generic way, from rain, a bucket of water, etc, not necessarily wet due to the sea/ocean)
sand that's hot enough to burn the feet
